tags: Building Uses - residential - observation - retail; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - streamline moderne; Materials - concrete
description:
Description
- Architects: Sánchez, Lagos, De la Torre



- Developer/Investor: Corina Kavanagh



- Upon its completion, this was the tallest building in Latin America.



- This was the tallest reinforced concrete building in the world when built.



- The investor, Corina Kavanagh, had to invest all she'd inherited to get this skyscraper built.



- The roof contains an outdoor/open-air observation area.



- The tower contains 10 storefronts on the ground floor.

name: Palacio Fuentes
tags: Building Uses - mixed use - museum - office - residential; Structural Types - highrise; Materials - marble - concrete - bronze
description:
Description
It is one of the most highlighted buildings in Rosario's architecture. It is located in front of El Cairo's bar and was built between 1922 and 1927. Intended to be the highest pinnacle in town: 65 meters tall.



It can be considered an open-sky museum, with many pieces of Art's history. In which we can see the faces of the owner, the project designer and other important caracters of its time.



The corner has an important bronzed-acces door, sorounded with columns. On the same corner we can see the tower with distint-decrescient-size levels. It is pinnacled with a weather vane. This tower has a four-cuadrant clock that plays the londoner Big Ben's sound.



In the beginning in 2011, on the basemen will hold the first museum dedicated to Democracy in Argentina.

tags: Building Uses - office; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - glass - concrete
description:
Description
Intended to complete the view from Parana's River and 'Bajada Sargento Cabral' (an historical attractive street), the building imitates the front of its inmediate neighbour "Farallon", one of the most significatives pieces of architecture in town, finished in 1970. The construction began late 2009, but financial problems freezed it until late 2010. Now it is again under-construction.

description:
Description
• Companies:

- Architect: Atelier SDG

- Contractor: Sunland Group

- Developer: Sunland Group

___________________________________________________________

Facts & Description:



• The name "Q1" is short for Queensland Number One.



• With the recent inclusion of the extented spire, it is now the World's tallest residential tower.



• Modifications to the podium level commercial space in November 2004 create better access to the tower and improve retail layout.  The tower is 50m across its plan shape of concentric ellipses.

name: Mount Wellington Broadcast Australia Tower
tags: Building Uses - communication; Structural Types - tower - truss tower; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - steel - concrete, reinforced
description:
Description
Developer: Broadcast Australia

Contractor: Broadcast Australia



This tower, Tasmania's tallest construction, sits atop windswept Mount Wellington over Hobart, and thus, is built to withstand the harsh weather conditions atop the summit.



This tower houses antenna and transmitters for many companies including Telstra (Australia’s largest telecommunication company), The Wireless Institute of Australia, Austar United, Vodafone (a mobile telephone telecommunication company), and three television stations.



The tower consists of a hollow, 67-metre-tall reinforced concrete base/shaft topped by a 64-meter-tall steel superstructure that supports an elevator and 3 antennas. The steel superstructure is wrapped in fiberglass to protect the antenna.

name: Rialto Towers
tags: Building Uses - office - mechanical - observation - parking garage - restaurant; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - glass - steel - concrete, reinforced
description:
Description
• Companies:

- Architect: Gerard de Pru and Partners

- Structural Engineer: W.L. Meinhardt and Partners Pty Ltd 

- Consultant Architect: Dino Burratini of Sydney 

___________________________________________________________

Facts & Description:



• Total Cost: $300 Million



• The Rialto Towers have a total of 67 floors counting basement and mechanical floors. The first five floors are used for underground parking. The next three floors are used for the lobby and a cafe. The next 54 floors are used for office. Floor 58 is the Observation Deck and the rest are used for mechanical and other uses.



• There are 1254 stairs to the Observation Deck.



• The Rialto Towers was the tallest building in the Southern Hemisphere 1985 - 2004, not counting spires. It is still the tallest office building by roof height in the Southern Hemisphere.



• Member of "World Federation of Great Towers".



• The 55th floor observation deck did not open until July 19, 1994.

description:
Description
Architect: Foster and Partners 

Architect: Hassell Pty Ltd 



- The Deutsche Bank Place is the second-tallest building in the world with fewer than 40 stories; only Al Faisaliyah Center in Riyadh is taller.



- Deutsche Bank occupies 40% of the office space.



- The Deutsche Bank Place has a full height atrium (Australia's tallest), cut only by skybridges, runs between the main transportation core and the office tower.

name: Chifley Tower
tags: Building Uses - office - mechanical - restaurant - retail; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - postmodern; Materials - glass - steel - concrete
description:
Description
Architect: Kohn Pederson Fox & Associates

Structural Engineer: Flack and Kurtz Australia  

Builder:  Multiplex Construction (NSW)  



- Development Cost: $1.2 Billion

Construction Cost: $425 Million



- Chifley Square is one of the most prestigious office and retail complexes in Australia. Located at a prime position on Macquarie Street, providing tenants with breathtaking views across Sydney Harbour.



- Built to counteract the tower swaying in high winds, a giant steel block pendulum weighing 400 tonnes is suspended from eight 75mm diameter steel wires located near the top floor. This is connected to a hydraulic dampened gravity system, thus stabilizing the building in high winds.

 

- The Exclusive 'Level 41' restaurant is situated 185m above street level in Chifley Tower.

description:

Architect: Lucien de Vestel 

Renovation Architects: Pierre Lallemand, Steven Beckers & Wilfried Van Campenhout 



- Between 1991 and 2004, the Berlaymont Building was completely renovated, including the revoming of large amounts of asbestos.



- From 1967 to 1991 the building was home of the European Commision. At the end of 2004, the European Commision will finally return to Berlaymont.

name: Madou Plaza
tags: Building Uses - office; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - glass - steel - concrete, reinforced
description:
Description
• Architect: ARCHI 2000 /ASSAR.

___________________________________________________________



• The new Madou Plaza replaced the old Madoutoren designed by architect Robert Goffaux. http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=39055



• The increase in surface required a complete building reshape and structural reinforcements like welding shells on certain steel beams, adding concrete columns in the basements and some strengthening of the foundations.



• For power requirements a high voltage transformer is located in the basement and a 1360 kW emergency generator was recently added.



• This high-rise won the prestigious MIPIM Award 2006 in the ‘Refurbished Office Buildings’ category.

description:
Description
• Constructor: Moura Dubeux. http://www.mouradubeux.com.br/

___________________________________________________________



• It was the Tallest Residential building in Recife from 2003 to 2005, when it surpassed Ed. Porto Seguro. http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=31903



• But then in 2005 the building lost the title of tallest building in Recife to Ed. Aderbal Jurema http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=28283

which in turn ceded the same title to Ed. Terra Brasilis, today the tallest Residential and all use Building in Recife Town. http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=28286



• Parnamirim is the same Neighborhood of the Headquarters of Improvements in North-East Region Sudene (Superintendencia de Desenvolvimento do Nordeste) which had a half block big Hause in Bauhaus Tendency Style, today destroyed, houses the Superintendente Man.

name: Palácio Gustavo Capanema
tags: Building Uses - office - government; Structural Types - highrise - stilts; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - glass - steel - aluminium - concrete (plain) - concrete, reinforced
description:
Description
• Architects: Carlos Leão, Ernani Vasconcellos, Affonso Eduardo Reidy, Jorge Machado Moreira, Le Corbusier, Lúcio Costa, Oscar Niemeyer. 



• Gardening: Roberto Burle Marx.

• Paintings: Cândido Portinari.

___________________________________________________________



• Home of the Ministry of Education and Health (also the building's original name), the building is now named after a prominent minister from the 1930s and 1940s.  



• An early example of Le Corbusier influences of Modernism at a large scale, the design was a team effort led by Oscar Niemeyer and Lúcio Costa, th building was asked to be near coast, but this never happened. 



• The first highrise building in the world to have a glass facade.



• In 2003 UNESCO gave the building the status of Historic Heritage of Mankind.



• Lobby of 9m.



• One of the fisrt buildings in world using brise-soleil againt Sun Radiation on North Facade.

name: Estrada de Ferro Central do Brasil
tags: Building Uses - office; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - art deco - modern; Materials - glass - steel - concrete, reinforced
description:
Description
• Architect: Robert R. Prentice.



• Operator: Supervia.

___________________________________________________________



• Brazil's Central Station is a railway station, located in the center of the city of Rio de Janeiro. By the year 1998 was dominated Estação Dom Pedro II, the name which is still known. 



• The previous building "Estação do Campo" built in 1858 inaugurated the line of the Railroad Center of Brazil. In time its name was changed to the "Estação da Corte" and, later, Dom Pedro II. The station today is called the Central do Brasil due to the old railroad extinguished in 1971 by decision of RFFSA. This was the informal name of the station, and became official after the filming of the movie that has this name, which had scenes in the rounds and competed for Oscar, with Fernanda Montenegro in the dispute by the best actress award in 1998. 



• The previous building built in 1858 was reformed years later and finally demolished in the 30s, to give rise to the present, because of the work of electrification and expansion of the system. 



• Trains out of several branches, linking the center to the other districts of North and West of Rio de Janeiro, and also the municipalities of the Baixada Fluminense, including the extension of Saracuruna / Gramacho, which originally came out of the garage of Baron de Mauá by belonging to the former Estrada de Ferro Leopoldina. 



• The clock on the top of the building, one of the biggest in world at 4 faces, was built by IBM and its diameter is 10 meters.



• The building has four setbacks, at 36.79 meters, 87.72 meters, 108.81 meters and 121.98 meters.

___________________________________________________________

name: Edifício Avenida Central
tags: Building Uses - office; Structural Types - highrise - landing pad; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - glass - steel - aluminium - concrete (plain) - concrete, reinforced
description:
Description
• Architect: Henrique Mindlin.



• Architect & Owner of site: Regine Feigl.

• Steel: CSN - Companhia Siderúrgica Nacional.

___________________________________________________________



• Architecture based on buidlings of Mies van der Rohe.



• It is located on the same site of the former building, Hotel Avenida, built in 1911, where had also the gallery Galeria Cruzeiro, terminal point of trams from Southern Zone, both demolished in 1958. 



• Its construction took 3 years and was inaugurated on May 22, 1961, the first building in the center of Rio de Janeiro in metal structure erected in place of reinforced concrete. 



• It is a building with 1,061 rooms and 200 stores. It was also the first to use the ; Architectural Style "tower-on-plate", ie the tower built on a plate which is located a shopping mall - in this case, a podium of 4 floors. 



• In its center is a center specializing in big sale of equipment for data processing and electro-electronics, the largest of Rio de Janeiro. This is due mainly to the performance of the company PromoInfo, which opened in 1994, called Info centers - the principle of two, and now, with four floors of the commercial center of the building.

description:
Description
• Architects: Pontual Arquitetura, Robert A.M. Stern Architects LLP. 



• Engineers: CRAFT Engenharia.

• Project: Datum Consultoria e Projetos Ltda.

• Constructors: DENB-RIO, Gafisa S.A., Hines Interests LP, Jones Lang LaSalle Inc., ThyssenKrupp Elevadores S.A. (Lift).

• Tenant: Petróleo Brasileiro S.A.

___________________________________________________________



• After Construction started in December 2002, building was completed on October 6, 2004 and opened to the public on November 17, 2004.



• This was the first building completed in downtown Rio de Janeiro after 2000, a project to revitalize Rio´s downtown promoted by the municipality.



• The lobby features a spectacular 20-foot-high, back-lit onyx wall visible through a full-height glass entry.



• Former Andorinha in site, inaugurated in 1934 with 12-floors, was demolished after a huge fire in February 17, 1986, killing 21 people, 50 injuries. The fire started in GE Headquarters at 9 floor. In the new project, the facade forms of Edifício Andorinha were based on, to be resembled in the new project for lower floors, the same height relation of new and old buidling, as memory and touches of old construction in facade the new glassy tower. 



• The facade's illumination system is capable of generating 16 million different colours. 



• The construction trash was recycled and transformed into more than 500,000 concrete bricks.



• Each standard floor has 1.600 m².

___________________________________________________________

description:
Description
• Architects: Aflalo & Gasperini Arquitetos, Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates PC http://www.kpf.com/main.asp.



• Constructors: Acústica & Sônica, Arcelor Brasil, Arq e Urb Projetos, Beltec Engenharia Ltda, Bosco & Associados Ltda, Brasiliano & Associados, Camargo Correa Desenvolvimento Imobiliario, Concremat, DW/Santana, Engemix, Engenheiros Consultores Associados Consultrix S/C Ltda., Gondomatic Representações Ltda., HR Assessoria Aeronáutica, Israel Berger & Associates, Jones Lang LaSalle Inc., Júlio Kassoy & Mário Franco, Knauf do Brasil Ltda., Laboratório de Aerodinâmica da Construção/UFRGS, MAC Protensão, Meta Núcleo de Projetos e Serviços Ltda., Método Engenharia Ltda., MHA Engenharia, MVS, PROASSP - Assessoria e Projetos, Teknika Projetos e Consultoria SC Ltda., Tengel Engenharia, ThyssenKrupp Elevadores S.A., Tishman Speyer GmbH & Co., Vecotec Sistemas de Climatização.

___________________________________________________________



• The building has two helipads, one in each tower. 

• Excavation started in March 2006 and construction in April 2006, which the project was renamed from Rio Towers to Ventura Corporate Towers. 

• Construction of the first phase began in April 2006.  Phase A of this project was topped out in October 2007. Construction of Phase A was completed three months ahead of schedule, in July 2008.

• The second phase of the project, the Phase and Tower B, was scheduled to be finished by 2010. Excavation works for the Phase B started in December 2007.

• The site where this building is located has 8550 m² of area, which was purchased from UFRJ (Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro). 

• Rain and condensation waters' from the air-conditioning systems is used to irrigate the landscaped areas. 

• The building is LEED certified. 

• In total, there are 42 elevators: 22 in Phase A and 20 in Phase B. 

• There is 2,400 m² of retail in entrance level.

• Both buildings has 36 habitable storeys, 32 common floors, Ground Floor, 1 mezaninos and 1 terrace atop and 1 mechanical lower heliport atop. An attached 5-storeys Garage building + 5 basement is seen in project for 1500 vehicles.

name: Edifício Santos Dumont
tags: Building Uses - office - parking garage - restaurant; Structural Types - highrise - landing pad - revolving floor - concrete core; Architectural Style - international - modern; Materials - masonry - glass - steel - aluminium - concrete (plain) - concrete, reinforced - brick
description:
Description
• Architect: Max Gruzman Arquitetura.



• Constructor: Servenco - Serviços de Engenharia Continental. Project of 1970.

___________________________________________________________



• Site: 1300 m².



• Construction began on November 3rd, 1971 and inaugurated on November 1975. On its inauguration, was the tallest building in Rio de Janeiro state and the one with most storeys. It had the first rotated restaurant in top of a building in South América, today not in operation anymore.



• The first 6 of the 45 floors are parking levels. 



• The central core was built in only 58 days.



• Construction History: 



- The bold project would face its first hurdle to begin the excavation of the soil. Just below the surface of the old wharf, traces of previous season of successive landfills were found, when the sea was in this street. It was necessary to overcome the thick wall of stone, which came to meet up to 9 meters deep, and as many wide. 



- In October 1971, overcoming the obstacles, the work continued until his fundamental point, the slidding frame with reinf. concrete core, one of the most advanced construction methods of the time, a technological challenge, which would be held with the central core. 



- During 3 years, 11 months and some days, the work was being raised from 20 meters below the ground up to 140 meters high from the surface. On November 3, 1971 the site began to be prepared to allow the start of work on foundations. Besides the conventional polls, penetration tests were performed to measure the static strength of the soil and to better determine the depth of settlement of tubes. This information was provided by a device, called penetrometer hydraulic motor, which controls the strength of the field almost 20 by 20 centimeters, is used, usually in large-scale works. 



- Analyzed the results of polls, was chosen by the foundation tubes with reinforced concrete, because there would be a concentration of cargo up to two tons in the pillars. It was used a total of 21 foundations tubes shirt of concrete, with diameters ranging between 1.70 and 2 meters, and 49 metal stakes and 25 profiles of scores. 



- The central pillars of the blade were prepared to receive loads of up to 2,350 tonnes. The foundations have been implemented with the placement in a circle in the center of the land, in nine major tubes. These were topped by a block of crowning in the shape of octagon, measuring 1.80 meters in height and 13 meters away from face to face. Consumption of this block was 80 tonnes of iron and 1,400 bags of cement. Soon after concreting the floor of the sub-soil and, after ten months and 53 thousand man-hours of work in the foundations, the building appeared above the surface. 



- Work on the building structure, however, had not yet finished, because only half of the pillars rises until the last of the five floors of parking. Because of this, to embrace these pillars, there was above the block of parking deck of a structural transition, with 3.80 meters, 1.20 meters wide and 90 meters in length, new pillars, running as a kind of higher foundation. The core, which part of this point, has the function of a central pillar joining with radial beams all of floors. 



- After three concrete decks using conventional forms, there was the lifting of the core through the sliding ways. The sliding forms moved up in the vertical direction supported by the strength of hydraulic jacks, leaving them under a structure of concrete already armed. These hydraulic jacks reacted on resistant steel tubes tablets which were placed inside the form, embedded in the walls of concrete. 



- After filling concrete, the monkeys were climbing, guided by tubes of elevation, in steps of approximately six centimeters. Through this system, rose 43 floors in the space of 58 days, gaining time and security in the increase of more than 121 meters. 



- It began the process of masonry, after bricks. The building was then outside the format of a huge tree of concrete, with concrete slabs apparently connected by radial beams to its core. It was used aluminum frames for windows. The floors used 2000 meters of peroba wood pieces and 11000 meters of ipê wood pieces. In 4400 of the facade windows were applied 8000m² of glass crystal bronze, 6 mm, imported from Japan and were used in front, 11,000 meters in natural color, 96ton anodized aluminium. The facade was completed with the varnishing of concrete, using varnish-based resin, polyurethane, impermeable. 



- And when, in November 1975, Servenco gave to Aeronautics Club, the highest building of State, it was a point of reference for Rio de Janeiro city. The building was inaugurated with the name "Building Aeronautics' Club", but was later changed and nominated Santos Dumont Building, where the headquarters of the Club of Aeronautics returned to its old premises in Praça Marechal Âncora, next to COMAR III. 



• The total area has been built up with: 



- 140,000 bags of cement. 

- 3,008,683 Watts of Electric total capacity power.

- 13,000 m³ of sand.

- 11,500 m³ of crushed stone. 

- 1,900 tons of structural cross-beams. 

- 1,724 tons, cooling capacity. 

- 14,000 meters of pipes for water installations. 

- 4,400 windows in the building.

- 957 records.

- ~ 620,000 bricks used in construction. 

- 53,000 man-hours in service foundations. 

- 49 metal stakes. 

- 1,274,000 liters of water distributed in 8 tanks.

___________________________________________________________



• Photo Link: http://www.panoramio.com/photo/5366999

description:
Description
• Tower Architect: Jozias Marques.



• Constructor: Incorporadora Paulista.

• Tower Owner: Rede Globo de Televisão.

• Paint: WEG

___________________________________________________________



• This building contains a 115-meter truss-tower communications tower on its roof as digital Television Antenna from TV Globo. At night the ilumination of Tower is a kind of Dynamic Rainbow colouring the City Mark Skyline. Weight: 200 tons.



• The function of tower is the transmition of communication signals of Globo Television Net, first sent from Pico do Jaraguá Tower, channel 19 TVA and after all the digital signals, while Analogue Tower atop Casper Líbero nearby could not receive both signals' types.



• Construction of the telecommunications tower began and ended before the building's completion, finished in April 2006.



• One of Tallest Structures in city on the highest hill in region, Av. Paulista.



• General Consulate of Australia is in Building.

___________________________________________________________

description:
Description
Originally constructed for Caixa Econômica Federal (Brazil main Federal Savings Bank), which still a bank agency at ground floor remains, the structure was bought by the Tribunal Regional Federal da Terceira Região in 1989 and subsequently renovated, and official reopened by Tribunal on 22 February 1999.



The Regional Federal Court of the Third Region was created together with others four Regional Federal Courts, for the Constitution of 1988 (article 27, § 6 and * 186;, of the Act of the Constitutional Transitory Arrangements), with the objective to substitute and regionalizing the jurisdiction of the extinct Federal Court of Resources (TFR).



The Regional Federal Courts were inaugurated simultaneously thirst in Sao Paulo, Brasilia, Rio de Janeiro, Porto Alegre and Recife on the 30th of March of 1989, and they had his initial compositions predicted in the law #186; 7.727, of 1989.



This is twin tower of:

http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=63590

description:
Description
• Architect: Aflalo & Gasperini Arquitetos http://www.aflaloegasperini.com.br



• Constructor: Construtora OAS Ltda.

• Tenants: Citibank S.A., Sheraton WTC Hotel, Meliá Brasil Adm. Hotel Com. Ltda., Regus Management Ltda., The Walt Disney Company, Alcan Composites, Novell do Brasil, Cummins Brasil Ltda., Vale do Rio Doce and many others.

___________________________________________________________



• The building is part of the World Trade Center Complex, of about 161801m² of area, located at Marginal Pinheiros river near Berrini Avenue, which has an office tower, Hotel Sheraton (Former Grand Meliá of 1995) and Shopping D&D Decoration & Design, among other facilities.



• In Office tower, occupied from several companies, has the automated remote control system, optimization of operation and maintenance functions, the constant supervision of the sub-lighting, the lifts, air-conditioning and others systems. 



• All points of control of air-conditioning, security systems, alarms and fire detectors are controlled by the automation system BMS (Building Mangement Systems), specifically for administration of the office tower.



• Each floor has a telematic system that has a network of fiber optic structured wiring, which makes the facilities of communication systems, voice, data and image.



• The complex is also pioneering the concept of Teleport in São Paulo, providing all telecommunications facilities necessary for the proper functioning of a company. 



• It has a gas power plant with generating capacity of 5.25 MW, enough to supply a town of 5,000 inhabitants.

___________________________________________________________



• Photo Links: 

1- http://www.panoramio.com/photo/7907734

2- http://www.panoramio.com/photo/14576212

Description
Architect: Ruy Othake Arquitetura e Urbanismo

Construction Company: Blokos Engenharia Ltda.



In its entrance a castle-house built between years 1880-1890, influenced the architecture of the building, forming a strong curve, avoiding the destruction of the house as it is a historic monument under protection of the government. Renovated from building constructors, it is the focal point in contrast to the blue glass curtain of the highrise.



Project developed by Fundação Carlos Chagas, the building is further used by Tribunal de Justiça do Estado de São Paulo.



With its 11750m2 of glass facade. It is known as new Copan.

Chieko Aoki, a japanese woman immigrant was the owner of Caeser Park 5-Stars hotels in Sao Paulo, Rio de Janeiro and Fortaleza. She sold those own built Caesar Park hotels to make a bigger hotels net, the Blue Tree Towers, not top 5-Stars hotels anymore, but with excelent services of such appartments hotels for business spread in business offices buildings neighboorhoods in many cities, a different approach of Caeser Park hotels.

name: Predio Martinelli
tags: Building Uses - office; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - art deco; Materials - glass - steel - granite - stucco - concrete, reinforced - brick
description:
Description
• Architect: Irmãos Lacombe. 



• Engineer: Engenheiro Walter Merlo.

• Former Owner: naval constructor Comendador Giuseppe Martinelli.

___________________________________________________________



• The construction of the building began in 1922 and it was inaugurated in 1929 with 12 floors. The construction of the building followed until 1934. The work ended when the building had 30 floors



• Predio Martinelli was Sao Paulo's first skyscraper. In 1947 it lost its title to the nearby Edificio Altino Arantes. It also was the first high rise building in Brazil and in Latin America taller than 100 meters.



• Former owner Italian Immigrant Martinelli and his wife lived in a four-story mansion on top of the building. It was only accessible by a private elevator and had a terrace and garden.



• Cement for concrete was imported from Norway and Sweden.



• The building hosted the first luminous advertisement in São Paulo, installed in 1929 and removed a few years later.  



• Due to financial difficulties in 1934, Martinelli sold the building to the Italian government.



• In 1943, with Brazil joining World War II, all Italian properties were confiscated by the Brazilian government, including this building, renaming it Edifício América. After the war the original name was used again.



• In 1992 the building became historical heritage by city hall. 

  

• In the 1950ies the building was invaded and occupied for years by poor families using the office building as a residence.



• Between 1975-1979 the building was restored by Mayor Olavo Setúbal.

  

• Initially the project was a 12-stories building, the project was changed later to 14, 20, and finally 30 stories. Actually the building itself has 26-storeys while the Mansion atop has 4 floors.



• Stories abound of the building being haunted by a ghost called "the blonde lady with no face", seen only in mirrors.



• Several political parties had their headquarters in Building, the former PRP, PC, PI, then the UDN. The clubs also occupied their dependencies Palestra Itália, today the Palmeiras, the Portuguesa de Desportos and IT, now disappeared. Today has 'Secretarias Municipais de Habitação e Planejamento', Emurb, Cohab-SP and 'Sindicato dos Bancários de SP'.

___________________________________________________________



• Info Page: http://www.piratininga.org/Martinelli.htm



• Old Photo: http://theurbanearth.files.wordpress.com/2008/08/240_martinelli.jpg

tags: Building Uses - office - restaurant; Structural Types - highrise - landing pad; Architectural Style - international - postmodern; Materials - glass - steel - aluminium - granite - concrete, reinforced
description:
Description
• Zona Sul.



Companies:

• Architect: Arquitectonica.



• Constructor: WTorre Empreendimentos (Walter Torres Emp.), Isabel Duprat, Grumont Equipamentos. 

• Ex-Owner: Ergi Empreendimentos.

• New Owner & Tenant: Banco Santander.

___________________________________________________________

Facts & Description



• Originally constructed by Andrade Gutierrez to be the Eletropaulo Headquarters in middle of the 80ies, after troubles, like the quality of the ground, the building was demanding extra reinforcement in his foundations, which also was raising the price of the project and due to the privatization of the company in 1998, the new owners put the building in auction several times till the Portuguese bank Holy Spirit bought it for somewhat more of R$ 140 millions, construction was stopped leaving only the concrete frame completed. Only in 2006, the Portugueses sold the space for around R$ 350 millions to the W/Torre.



• In March 2007 a crane was assembled atop the building, the same month that construction resumed after several years on hold.



• The first project designed by Aflalo & Gasperini Arquitetos with a spire of 150.9m, using Eletropaulo Structure concrete frame, was modified by Arquitectonica when WTorre Empreendimentos bought the unfinished building from Eletropaulo. Before that as Eletropaulo Headquarters (Companhia Elétrica de Sao Paulo) too many expectulations were made, implosion of the structure cause of water infiltration problems, a huge tower of 40 floors with shopping and other ones, lefting the unfinished frame unused for years.



• The total number of floors was increased from 32 to 35, but when construction resumed (in 2007) the top four floors were demolished, reducing the building height to 28 floors. Only then the 7 new floors were built.



• This mixed-use development consists of three phases. The first phase of the project involves the design of the building facade and interiors for a 90.430 m² existing structure to be fitted out as an office tower, including floor plan layouts and interior design of lobbies and common area. This phase also includes the construction of six levels of underground parking with a total of 164.349 m². This tower is the first incorporation of WTorre JK, which includes 3000m² of floors, with 2750m² of use area, conventional center for 300 people, theater with 270 places, 2 restaurants, coffe-shop, Heliport Class P10 24x24m among other amenities.



• The second and third phase will be called Juscelino Kubitschek Financial Center with an expansion of Shopping Iguatemi, a hotel tower and a smaller office mix-used tower:

http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=73211 

A skybridge would be implemented to reach the new theater for community, renovating the park in front, called Parque do Povo, in which WTorre spends R$6 million its 112000 m², the same area of Aclimação Park,using 5000 tons of constructions garbage of project Nova Luz, near Luz Central Trains Station (Estação da Luz), with implementations like public swimming pools, Football court and Identified noble Trees, among other public activities in leisure affairs, project of André Graziano near Ponte Cidade Jardim for SP city in Gilberto Kassab city hall administration.



• Construction was resumed in early 2007, and four people were killed during the installation of a second construction crane atop the building in 25.June of that year.



• Banco Santander bought the building recently for its Headquarters, the most expensive transation made in Brazil until today. Cost of R$1.06 billion (US$650 million).

name: Edifício Altino Arantes
tags: Building Uses - office - museum; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - art deco; Materials - glass - steel - wood - marble - stucco - concrete, reinforced - concrete
description:
Description
• Architects: Franz Heep, Plínio Botelho do Amaral. 



• Owner: Banco Santander, ex-Sede Banco Banespa.



• Constructors: Construtora Camargo & Mesquita , Plínio Botelho do Amaral , FWT Técnica em Revestimentos, Franki, Empresa Concessionária de Produtos Ltda., Elevadores Atlas Schindler, Indústria Paulista de Porcelanas Argilex, Metal Tupy, Schwartz-Hautmont, Tarumã Engenharia. 

___________________________________________________________



• The Empire States Buidling in New York inspired constructor, changing the original project by Camargo & Mesquita construction company the original project from Plínio Botelho do Amaral, resembling it.



• Its construction was holded during World War II and resuming after the war, begun in September 13, 1939 and finished almost eight years later on June 27, 1947. The first foundation stone was placed by São Paulo former governor, Ademar de Barros.



• Tallest concrete structure in the world from 1947 until 1962, surpassing Prédio Martinelli as the tallest building in São Paulo and afterwords surpassed by Mirante do Vale was completed in same centre and also by Marina City I in Chicago.



• In 1951 the observation deck was opened to public  visitation on weekdays. Every month about 5600 people visit the observation deck.

 

• The main lobby floor-to-ceiling height is 16 meters, all covered in Marble, and in 1988 received a 13 meter tall luster with more than 1.5 tons weight. The piece has 150 lamps and 10 thousand crystal accessories.



• It has 1119 windows and its staircase has 900 steps.

 

• Although it is not the tallest in the city, is located on the highest point of old downtown, with the observation deck one of the best spots in town for sightseeing.

 

• The building facade is covered by porcelain pieces; inside the building some floors are decorated with Carrara marble, Ipê and Jacarandá parquet wood.



• In the 1960´s the building was renamed from Edifício Sede do Banespa to Altino Arantes in honor of the first Brazilian president of the bank. After privatization the state bank, Banco Santander removed the big 'Banespa' sign atop in July 2007, but until today is not again placed because the law in city avoiding signs and Propaganda visual pollution.



• Its bank vault, which has circular doors of sixteen tons each, was made by York Safe & Lock Co. from New York. It offers 2,000 safety deposit boxes in several sizes.



• The flag atop the structure is 7.2m high and 5.4 meters wide. Because huge wind the flag is replaced every month. It is the Coat of Arms and SP city flag symbol.

  

• There is a museum in its 3rd floor, with photos of the 40´s of objects the inauguration time and newspaper articles about the building.



• There are three water reservoirs in the tower - one in the basement, one in the 17th floor and one in the 31st floor.



• The foundation pillars reach a 14m maximum depth.



• The facade that faces Praça Antônio Prado is clad in 20,000 sq meters of ceramic tiles.

___________________________________________________________



• Photo Link: http://i2.photobucket.com/albums/y37/gutooo/banespa2.jpg

name: e-Tower
tags: Building Uses - office - parking garage - restaurant - fitness center; Structural Types - highrise - atrium - landing pad - pole; Architectural Style - postmodern; Materials - glass - steel - aluminium - granite - concrete
description:
Description
• Architect: Aflalo & Gasperini Arquitetos.

http://www.aflaloegasperini.com.br



• Constructor: Tecnum Construtora/Munir Abbud Empreendimentos Imobiliários. 



• Companies: BESP, Engebrat Consultoria, Ricardo França, Érika Luna, DW/Santana, Soeng Construção Hidro-elétrica Ltda, Mingrone, MHA Engenharia, Apoio Assessoria e Projetos de Fundações S/C Ltda, Acústica & Sônica, AEC Consultoria, HR Assessoria Aeronáutica, Laboratório de Aerodinâmica da Construção/UFRGS, Engemix, ThyssenKrupp Elevadores, S.A., Gondomatic Representações Ltda., YKK do Brasil, PROASSP - Assessoria e Projetos. 

__________________________________________________________



• The tower's designed is inspired by that of the Westendstraße 1 in Frankfurt and broke the world record for concrete resistance, 149 Mpa with a 10m high lobby floor-to-ceiling.



• Originally proposed to be taller, the height was scaled back because of the heavy helicopter traffic in the area and the approach of Congonhas Airport Routes.



• The tower contains a fitness center on its 20th floor, a restaurant on the 19th floor, and a heated swimming pool on the 37th floor. The balcony on the 9th floor is for private use only.



• The ground floor includes an auditorium that seats 100 persons.



• Total height from the 4th level underground to the top of the helipad is 161.9m.  



• The building sign sculpture was designed by Marcelo Aflalo, but was finally not included together the half site water mirror. 



• The building is composed of three different volumes with such area for each floor:

- 03rd to the 07th: 1100m² of net area,

- 08th to the 19th: 850m² of net area, 

- 22th to the 37th: 550m² of net area.



• The building site is 6350m². If count the Ground floor building has 38-storey, where the 38 one is a share of swimming pool used from fittness center, mechanical floor and a future restaurant not yet definied.

___________________________________________________________



• Info Page: http://www.arcoweb.com.br/arquitetura/arquitetura648.asp



• Rendering: http://www.pef.usp.br/VSimp/images/eTower.jpg

• Architect: Oscar Niemeyer & Carlos Lemos.



• Constructor: Engenharia e Construção Otto Meinberg S.A.

___________________________________________________________



• The buildings' name is inspired by that of the Copan Mayan Temple in Honduras.



• This is the largest residential building in Brazil, and, reportedly, the most populated single residential building in the world housing 5,000 listed in the Guinness Book of World Records as the largest structure built in Brazil an also claims this building has the largest floor area of any residential structure in the world, with a population greater than that 547 of Brazilian cities, according to IBGE (Instituto Brasileiro de Geografia e Estatística), a major research institute in Brazil.



• The ground floor is home to 70 businesses/establishments including, but not limited to, a church, travel agency, and library, and 4 restaurants.



• The building was originally constructed with a helipad that is no longer used.



• The condominium building has 107 employees to serve and maintain it.

 

• Due to the large number of residents, the Correios, Brazilian Post Office, gave the building its own ZIP code. 

 

• The building site is 10572.80 m².

name: Edificio Italia
tags: Building Uses - office - communication - residential - restaurant - retail - theatre; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - glass - steel - concrete, reinforced - concrete
description:
Description
• Architect: Franz Heep.



• Constructors: Grupo Comolatti, Cecchi & Cia Ltda., Engenharia e Construção Otto Meinberg S.A.

___________________________________________________________



• Built to honor the thousands of Italian immigrants to SP city, designed as a triangular tower with curved corners and is covered with brise-soleil. During its construction phase, the building started to inclinate. Freeze soil was necessary to keep it vertical. This brought the construction company to bankrupcy and the building is today a little bit lower the street level.



• Upon completion, Edifício Itália became the 2nd tallest building in city.



• On the 45th floor is the Terraço Itália restaurant used also as observation deck. Atop has some communication devices.  

  

• The facade has 6,000m² of glass distributed in 4,000 windows.



• It is popular known to be São Paulo's tallest building, a title that actually belongs to Mirante do Vale. Because its popularity, some ones tried to climb the building.



• An 18 month re-fit of the facade was completed in 2006 at a cost of US$ 700,000 (R$ 1,5 million).

 

• The building is 168 meters in height when measured from the underground level to its roof.



• At building has Circolo Italiano, Italian Club as well as Restaurant Terraço Itália in two decks mounted atop.

___________________________________________________________



• Photo Links: 

1- http://knaumann.sites.uol.com.br/TerracoItalia.JPG

2- http://www.bacante.com.br/blog/uploaded_images/file-735200.jpg

3- http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2157/2387603942_83cdd7e18e.jpg?v=0

name: Mirante do Vale
tags: Building Uses - mixed use - observation - office - residential - restaurant - retail; Structural Types - highrise - landing pad; Architectural Style - international - modern; Materials - glass - concrete, reinforced - concrete
description:
Description
• Owner: Zarzur Kogan.

___________________________________________________________



• Location: Vale do Anhangabaú, Centre BR-01031-902.



• The building, highest building in São Paulo and in Brazil, it is not very known, changed name to Mirante do Vale from Palácio Zarzur Kogan in 1988, a reference to the decadent coffee aristocracy, and was renovated that year, as well.



• Population: The building admits 10,000 people in normal activities and floating 30,000 per day. 

 

• Shops: 146 units.

• Offices: 812 units. 

• Business lounges: 60 units. 

• Elevators:  12 (speed of 320m/min), divided by areas. 

• Escalators:  2. 

• Restaurant: Installed in the 45 th floor.

• Mirante: 46 to the 50th floor.

• Heliport: 51 floor - Capacity of the runway landing 700 m. 

 

• Technical Data:

 

- Concrete: 20,000 tons. 

- Cement: 250,000 bags. 

- Steel: 5000 tons.

- Glass and frames: 25,000 m.

 

• Foundations: stakes to 20 meters deep. 

 

• Light and Power: 5,000 KW/h.

name: Obelisco Parque Ibirapuera
tags: Building Uses - monument - cemetary; Structural Types - tower; Architectural Style - italianate; Materials - marble - concrete, reinforced
description:
Description
• Architect: Oscar Niemeyer.



• Sculptures: Galileu Emendabile.

___________________________________________________________



• Poscode: BR-04094-000.

• Date of inauguration: 09.07.1955.



• The Obelisk of the Ibirapuera, monument that pays tribute to heroes of the Revolution Constitutional of 1932, is a project of the Italian sculptor Galileo Emendabili, who reached Brazil in 1923 escaping of the fascist regime established in his country. The monument was inaugurated officially a year after the inauguration of the Park of the Ibirapuera in 1954.



• Its construction began in 1947 and was ended only in 1970. Knocked down by the state and municipal councils of preservation of the historical inheritance, the mausoleum that exists inside the Obelisk guards the ashes of four students killed during a protest against the first government Swampy lowlands - Martins, Miragaia, Drausio and Camargo-, whose initials form the acronym MMDC, the great symbol of the revolution. The existent crypt in the Monument also maintains the ashes of another 713 ex-combatants. 



• Revolution of 1932 and War Of São Paulo were the names given to the armed movement occurred in Brazil between July and October of 1932 aiming at the falling of the provisional government of Getúlio Vargas and to the institution of a constitutional regime after the abolition of the Constitution of 1891 for the Revolution of 1930. 



• From the graves of the heroes, in the basement of the Monument, up to the top there are 81 meters, number which sum of the numerals and the square root turn in 9. The height of the Obelisk belongs of 72 meters: again the sum is the same as 9. There are nine steps in the entry and, internally, there are three groups of three arches, forming 9 arches, joined " in the triple perfection ". The length of the base of the Obelisk has 9 meters, it at the top has 7 meters, and the width of the crypt has 32 meters, in other words, the date of the revolution: 09.07.1932. 



• The simbology is also present in the drawing of the lawn around the Monument, which has area of 1.932 square meters and forms a heart where the sword (symbol of the Obelisk) pass though, that consecrated the political victory, in spite of the military defeat of the persons from Sao Paulo. At last, while seeing his government in risk, president Getúlio Vargas gives beginning to the process of reconstitucionalization of the country, leading to the promulgation in 1934 of a new Constitution.

___________________________________________________________



• Photo Link: http://www.sampaonline.com.br/postais/obelisco2001out26.jpg

• One of Calgary's first office buildings with a post-modern design theme with a number of unique technological innovations' features like column-free floor plates and four-sided silicone glazing on most of the exterior. Windows' installation used structural adhesive rather than mechanical.



• The building also features an elegant and stunning lobby entrance of marble, granite and stainless steel.



• Skybridge designed by BKDI linked to adjacent building mirrored in front street.

name: The Bow
tags: Building Uses - office - garden - retail; Structural Types - highrise - atrium; Architectural Style - modern - structural expressionism; Materials - glass - steel - concrete, reinforced
description:
Description
• Architects: Foster & Partners, Zeidler Partnership Architects.



• Constructors: Matthews Southwest (Canada), Ledcor Construction, Halcrow Yolles, Gensler, Gustafson Guthrie Nichol Ltd., Sturgess Architecture, Transsolar KlimaEngineering. 

___________________________________________________________



• Once built, it will be the tallest building in Canada outside of Toronto.



• Building named after the river that runs beside Calgary's downtown.



• As of 2006, the largest North American development ever for Foster, the design architect. 



• Canada's first trussed-tube skyscraper similar to John Hancock Center and One Maritime Plaza. 



• The advanced design, that makes the building 30% lighter than any its size, uses glass and steel engineering, a steel-framed structure crescent-shaped, and a position which allows maximum sunshine, and also deals effectively with summer and winter wind patterns.



• The EnCana headquarters provides space for 3,200 employees, once housed in five buildings. 



• Areas:

- Typical floor: ~ 32000 ft².

- Retail and cultural space: 200000 ft².

 

• Canada's second largest building in floor space after First Bank Tower in downtown Toronto. 



• Site of 190,000ft² and covers most of one full city block in the two block complex, which also includes a 7-story building and an extensive park-like plaza. 



• Three floors, approximately 17 floors apart, will feature sky gardens, indoor park-like levels with trees and vegetation, with seating and meeting spaces serviced by express elevators. 



• On announcement day, the Total cost was estimated to be between $850 million and $1 billion.

description:
Description
• Fenwick Place is a 252 unit Student Residence maintained by Dalhousie University for Full Time Undergraduate students.  Named after a former Lieutenant-Governor of the Province of Nova Scotia (Sir William Fenwick Williams).



• The developer ambitiously started this project 1969 touting it as the tallest residential project east of Toronto, however it met with financial difficulties and by 1971 was at a standstill.  Dalhousie University assumed responsibility for the project and finished it as a Residence for students.



• Dalhousie University has recently sold the tower (2009)

name: Stade Olympique et La Tour de Montréal
tags: Building Uses - sports - observation - office - parking garage - restaurant - retail; Structural Types - tower - dome - highrise - stadium; Architectural Style - modern - futurism; Materials - steel - concrete, reinforced - fabric
description:
Description
• Architect: Roger Taillibert.

• Structural Engineering: SNC Lavalin Inc.

___________________________________________________________



• World's tallest stadium, world's tallest leaning tower.



• Costs at completion as of October 1998: $991 Million Canadian.



• Parking Spaces: 3,718.



• This building was build for Montreal's Summer Olympics in 1976, but wasn't fully completed until 1987.



• In 1998 the stadium's retractable roof was replaced with a non-retractable roof due to complications with wind.



• Stadium seats 55,389 people.



• Home of the Montréal Expo's, Montréals baseball team.



• In clear weather, you can have a 80km view from the Observation Deck (which has 3 floors).



• In 1991,a 55 Ton concrete beam fell and crashed on the walkway, forcing the tower to be closed. The Expos played the remainder of their home games on the road.



• Member of "World Federation of Great Towers".



• The cable car:

- Is 2 stories tall.

- Weighs 13.5T (when empty).

- Can accomodate 76 passengers (Top deck 42, Bottom deck 34).

- Moves 2.8m/sec (2 minutes to top).

- does 79 daily runs in peak season and 49 in off season.

- Is 4.5M wide, 6.0M deep and 4.5M high.

- Has a gyroscopic leveling system to keep it horizontal while moving up and down the tower.

- Has 600m  of 37mm cable.

- Runs along 266m of track.



• Dimensions

perimeter of stadium: 861 m

length of stadium: 292 m

width of stadium, excluding tower: 268 m

Source: official website

description:
Description
Architects: John Pearson and J. Omer Marchand 



The original Parliament Buildings were destroyed in a fire in 1916, so a new one was built. The only remaining part of the original building is the Parliament Library.



In 1952, an electrical short in the National Library started a fire. It was restored.

name: Hotel Saskatchewan
tags: Building Uses - hotel; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - neo-classical; Materials - limestone - brick
description:
Description
Architect: Ross & Macdonald

Developer: Canadian Pacific Railway



Most of the ; Materials used in this hotel's construction, including the Tyndall Stone cladding, were obtained locally.



Hotel Saskatchewan was the second attempt to build a grand railway hotel in Regina. The first hotel was the Chateau Qu'Appelle. Construction started, but it was never completed, when the Grand Trunk Railway went bankrupt. Regina's aldermen lobbied the Canadian Pacific Railway for a first-class hotel to attract more tourists. The partially-constructed Chateau Qu'Appelle was demolished in the 1920's and Canadian Pacific Railway purchased the girders for use in the Hotel Saskatchewan. The hotel became a favorite of royalty and political dignitaries.

name: Delta Bessborough
tags: Building Uses - hotel - restaurant - fitness center; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - chateau; Materials - masonry - brick
description:
Description
• The hotel is often referred to as "The Castle on the River."



• This hotel was built by Canadian National Railway, and was one of the last hotels built by railroads, in general, in Canada.



• The hotel began construction in February of 1930, and finished in 1932.  The hotel, though, did not open officially until December 10, 1935.



• In 1975, the 7th and 8th floors were converted to office space usage.

name: Bay-Adelaide Centre West
tags: Building Uses - office - retail; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - modern - neo-classical; Materials - glass - steel - concrete, reinforced
description:
Description
Architect: WZMH Architects

Developer: Brookfield Properties Corp.





• certified LEED Gold core & shell





• Existing 6 storey elevator shaft from previously incomplete 57 Story Office tower to be demolished and made into an urban plaza.



• A 11-storey historic façade of the former National Building, with retention & integration of historically listed building 347 Bay Street, is restored, preserved and incorporated in building entrance.

 

• Retail concourse level with PATH system connection.



• Launched in the boom of 1980 years, a 57-storeys tower was to be constructed with a cost about US$ 1 billion. It was controversal from opposites of massive huge structures, because it would be higher than official plans. To be approved, the developers spent US$ 80 million in other projects. Construction although began in 1990 and due to recession, it was stopped on-hold in 1993 after spending US$ 500 millions on it. The parking garage and concrete shaft stood as monument in city downtown, known as 'the bunker' or 'the stump'. In 1998 TrizecHahn revived it for short time. In 2000 was revived again, when TrizecHahn sold 50% to Brookfield for about US$ 49 millions, declaring it would be shorter. Only in 2005 the project restarted with towers of about 43 to 50 storeys for tenants KPMG and Goodmanns LLP. On December 11, 2006 the construction restarted and was finished with 51 storeys in July 2009.



First design - http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=1494



Second design - http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=84221

description:
Description
• Originally proposed at 70 floors, and with a Ritz-Carlton hotel, no longer involved since May 10, 2002, the project has since been scaled back, and Ritz-Carlton dropped from the plan.



• The project is to include a 5-star, 261-room hotel, and 118 residential condominiums units.



• Received approval February 4th, 2003. 



• An early design featured an illuminated 100-foot titanium dome. 

 

• The tower will feature an 18,000 square foot health club and spa with views of Lake Ontario, two restaurants, and a sushi/martini bar.



• In July 2007 the building's story-count was reduced with the removal of 11 residential floors and two hotel floors, two mechanical systems floors were retained resulting in a reduction from 70 to 59 floors.

tags: Building Uses - office - communication - retail; Structural Types - highrise - guyed mast - sign; Architectural Style - international; Materials - glass - steel - stone - marble - concrete, reinforced

Architect: Bregman + Hamann Architects.

Developer: Olympia & York Properties Corp.

Developer: Bank of Montreal.

Owner: Brookfield Properties Corp. (2009)



• Canada's tallest building since 1975.



• 10,000 people work at the First Canadian Place every weekday, 16 million people visit the First Canadian Place annually.



• Tallest building in the Commonwealth of Nations from 1975 to 1998, surpassed by the Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.



• When the First Canadian Place was completed it was the tallest building outside the United States and eighth tallest in the world.



• The building is currently (2010) having it's clading replaced.  The original marble cladding has weathered considerably, marring the look of the tower, and it is being replaced with white fritted glass panels.  The indented corners of the tower will become black in color as well.

name: CN Tower
tags: Building Uses - communication - observation - restaurant; Structural Types - tower - glass floor - pod - revolving floor - exterior elevator; Architectural Style - futurism; Materials - glass - steel - concrete, reinforced - concrete
description:
Description
Design architect: John Andrews International



The CN Tower was the world's tallest free-standing structure and had the world's hightest public observatory until 2010 when Dubai's Burj Khalifa officially took on the title.



The tower is said to have 147 floors as the internal staircase has that many levels from the ground up to the Skypod, a public observation deck.



The tower was constructed by Canadian National Railroad to improve television reception.



There was a Pepsi logo on the north side of the white ring in 2002.



The CN Tower cost $63 Million (CAD) to construct.



Member of "World Federation of Great Towers."

name: Marine Building
tags: Building Uses - office - restaurant - retail; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - art deco; Materials - copper - steel - brick
description:
Description
Constructed between Mar 1929 and Oct 1930, this art deco building was the tallest building in the British Empire for a brief period of time. Developed by Toronto-based Stimson's Canadian Development Company, the Marine Building featured what were the fastest elevators in North America west of New York. At 700 feet per minute, the elevators are typical of what is found in new buildings. The contractor was E.J. Ryan Contracting Co Ltd., which also built Hotel Vancouver. Cost overuns made a $1.25 million project into $2.35 million.

name: 200 Granville Square
tags: Building Uses - office - communication - traffic control - retail; Structural Types - highrise - sign; Architectural Style - international; Materials - steel - concrete
description:
Description
Architect: Francis Donaldson



There has been some confusion over the height of this building because of the basement floors that are exposed on two sides.  Some sources give the height from the ground level on the harbour side of the building, while other sources give the height from the main entrance at the Granville Square level.  A model of the building at the entrance of Canada Place states that the height to the top of the facade is 375 feet or 114.3 meters.  This is measured from Granville Square.  The ground level on the harbour side of the building is 79 feet or 24 meters below Granville Square.



A station for harbour air traffic control is mounted at the top of this building.  This structure is included in the "roof" height for the building.  The roof of the mechanical penthouse is given as the "lower roof 1" height.

name: Bentall Five
tags: Building Uses - office - retail; Structural Types - highrise; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - glass - aluminium - concrete, reinforced
description:
Description
Architect: Musson Cattell Mackey Partnership

Developer: Bentall Capital



Bentall 5 is being constructed in two phases.  The first phase, finished in 2002, is a 22 floor office building.  The second phase, begun in summer 2005, will see 13 additional office floors built on top of the first phase, for a total of 35 floors.  The height of the first phase at completion is 96 meters.  The height of phase two will be 141 meters.  Originally, the height for phase two has been planned at 152 meters.  The foundation was built in the early 1990s, when there was a different design for the tower.



Gross floor area of phase 1 is 31,586 m².



Webcam: http://bentall5.com/webcam.asp



Information from architects Musson Cattell Mackey Partnership:



Phase 1

Top of crown = 474'-2" (elevation above sea level)

Ground floor datum = 159.39'

Total height = 314'-9 5/16"



Phase 2

Top of crown = 622'-5" (elevation above sea level)

name: One Wall Centre
tags: Building Uses - mixed use - conference - hotel - residential; Structural Types - highrise - tuned mass damper - pole; Architectural Style - modern; Materials - glass - concrete
description:
Description
Architect: Busby + Associates Architects

Developer: Wall Financial Corp.



One Wall Centre became one of the the tallest buildings in Vancouver at the time of its construction. The only structure in the city which was taller than it is the antenna on the top of Harbour Centre.



The two-toned appearance of One Wall Centre was the result of a conflict between the building's developer and Vancouver City Hall. During construction, dark blue glass was installed on the lower two-thirds of the building. City Hall did not like the look of the dark glass and so forced the developer to change to lighter glass, dispite the developer bribing city hall with three million dollars.



In 2013 the lighter glass on the upper third of the tower was replaced with dark blue glass to closely match the lower part of the tower.



The original design was to have two double-height garden levels one-third and two-thirds of the way up the tower. The lobby was to have a 60 foot ceiling.



Width: 21.3m
